title: Bi-Weekly Movies, TV Shows, Documentaries & Podcasts Discussion Thread
selftext:
So, what is r/India watching of late?

Watched any premieres yesterday? Loved any movie that you saw recently and are dying to discuss it? Discovered any new series lately? Well, this is your space. Go crazy!

This is not just limited to Hollywood/Bollywood, nor to any particular language.

Feel free to share short films, or podcasts of your choice, too, and ask for recommendations for what to watch!

**Movies and Shows Thread is posted every two weeks on Saturday mornings |** [**Old Threads**](https://reddit.com/r/india/search?q=Movies+thread+discussion+&restrict_sr=on&sort=new&t=all)

https://preview.redd.it/e3cqi5nuw8n61.png?width=1487&format=png&auto=webp&s=c6623226acf7856bb5a61313af7bec382c8525f1
comments: Watched PS-1 and I liked it. It tried to stick to the book and was low on mass hero build ups which is what I expected. Casting was really good. Hardcore masala movie fans should stay away though.

Vikram Vedha was a good watch.. it felt refreshing yet nostalgic.  Hrithik's Vedha and charm was what made the movie. Sprinkled with masala but not over the top. This coming from someone that doesn't like masala flicks

I don't know how much people go out of their way to watch movies not available on ott in India (sail the high seas!) but I recently watched Fall 2022 ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt15325794/?ref\_=nv\_sr\_srsg\_0](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt15325794/?ref_=nv_sr_srsg_0))

Plot: Best friends Becky and Hunter find themselves at the top of a 2,000-foot radio tower.

I am a horror fan and I love heavy gore movies, but watching this movie made my intestines turn like no other movie. It's different, it will take you on an adventure, it will take you with the characters on top of the 2000ft tower. I loved it.
Thanks for the recommendation, downloading. Will watch tomorrow.

Recently re-watched Adam Curtis's Bitter Lake. One of the best political/historical documentaries I've ever seen.

Would recommend to everyone regardless of political leaning. Even if you find yourself disagreeing with the director's take, you still get a fairly unbiased look into the events that led to the current situation in Afghanistan/ME. 

If you do end up enjoying the doc, don't hesitate to go down the Adam Curtis rabbit hole. Hypernormalisation, The Power of Nightmares, Can't Get you Out of my Head are all worth a watch 

Relevant links:-

Bitter Lake:

https://watchdocumentaries.com/bitter-lake/

HyperNormalisation:

https://watchdocumentaries.com/hypernormalisation/

The Power of Nightmares:

https://watchdocumentaries.com/the-power-of-nightmares/

Can't Get You Out of My Head:

https://watchdocumentaries.com/cant-get-you-out-of-my-head/
Let me know if you liked it mate
Have watched all of his films. Kinda expanded my understanding of the world.
